isValidPortableFileName

public static boolean isValidPortableFileName(java.lang.String strFileName)
Returns true if the given name is a valid portable file name.

Obviously we can't really make this determination in any absolute sense if we support an open ended set of operating/file systems. So we try to take a common denominator approach and permit names that contain characters in the domain defined by the intersection of conventional characters for "common" file systems.

For details regarding to FAT, NTFS, HPFS file systems see: http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;EN-US;100108

Invalid chars for: FAT32: "/\[]:;|=, NTFS: ?"/\<>*|: HPFS: /\ AIX: /\ UNIX: /\ note some characters have special meaning, but are legal e.g., '~'

Combined: "/\[]:;|=,?<>*

Note some older file systems are more strict, but for usability purposes we opt for more flexible naming conventions.

makeValidPortableFileName

public static java.lang.String makeValidPortableFileName(java.lang.String strFileName)

findFile

public static java.io.File findFile(java.lang.String startDir,
                                    java.lang.String fileName)
Finds a file in a directory tree. If the file exists more than once, the first one found is returned. Since Windows is case-insensitive, this search will also be case-insenstive.

Returns:
Found file, else null.

                                  FileBlock block,
                                  java.io.FileFilter dirPredicate)
Evaluates the given block on every File in the tree. If dirPredicate is specified, it can be used to filter which directories are traversed; if it's left null, all subdirectories will be traversed.

Parameters:
dir -

concatDirectories

public static java.lang.String concatDirectories(java.lang.String... directories)
Return a string of the given directories concatenated with File.separator characters seperating them. This is a safer way to write out paths as opposed to using '\\' and '/' characters.

Returns:
a path string, or the empty string there are no directories to contacenate.

readBytes

public static void readBytes(java.io.File f,
                             StreamBlock<? super java.io.BufferedInputStream> block)
                      throws java.io.IOException
Opens the given file in read mode, and passes a BufferedInputStream to the given block. Typically it's best to buffer a file-based input stream, as reading individual bytes from such a stream can be inefficient. Callers that want to work with a raw FileInputStream should use IOUtil.withOpenStream(com.guidewire.commons.io.StreamFactory, com.guidewire.commons.io.StreamBlock) directly.

Throws:
java.io.IOException

readChars

public static void readChars(java.io.File f,
                             StreamBlock<? super java.io.BufferedReader> block)
                      throws java.io.IOException
Opens the given file in read mode, and passes a BufferedReader to the given block. Typically it's best to buffer an InputStreamReader, as reading individual chars from such a reader can be inefficient. Callers that want to work with a raw InputStreamReader should use IOUtil.withOpenStream(com.guidewire.commons.io.StreamFactory, com.guidewire.commons.io.StreamBlock) directly.

Throws:
java.io.IOException

readLines

public static void readLines(java.io.File f,
                             LineBlock block)
                      throws java.io.IOException
Opens the given file in read mode, and passes each line to the given block. Lines are generated using BufferedReader.readLine(), so any end-of-line characters, as defined by that method, will not be included in the line.

Throws:
java.io.IOException

writeBytes

public static void writeBytes(java.io.File f,
                              StreamBlock<? super java.io.BufferedOutputStream> block)
                       throws java.io.IOException
Opens the given file in write mode, and passes a BufferedOutputStream to the given block. Typically it's best to buffer a file-based output stream, as writing individual bytes to such a stream can be inefficient. Callers that want to work with a raw FileOutputStream should use IOUtil.withOpenStream(com.guidewire.commons.io.StreamFactory, com.guidewire.commons.io.StreamBlock) directly.

Throws:
java.io.IOException

writeChars

public static void writeChars(java.io.File f,
                              StreamBlock<? super java.io.BufferedWriter> block)
                       throws java.io.IOException
Opens the given file in write mode, and passes a BufferedWriter to the given block. Typically it's best to buffer an OutputStreamWriter, as writing individual chars from such a writer can be inefficient. Callers that want to work with a raw OutputStreamWriter should use IOUtil.withOpenStream(com.guidewire.commons.io.StreamFactory, com.guidewire.commons.io.StreamBlock) directly.

Throws:
java.io.IOException

writeLines

public static void writeLines(java.io.File f,
                              java.lang.Iterable<? extends java.lang.CharSequence> lines)
                       throws java.io.IOException
Opens the given file in write mode, and writes each line returned by the given Iterable. End-of-line characters are written after each line, as defined by BufferedWriter.newLine().

Throws:
java.io.IOException

appendLines

getRelativeSrcDir

public static java.lang.String getRelativeSrcDir(java.lang.String product,
                                                 java.lang.String type)
Gives a source directory string relative to the devhome (commons,src) => "platform/commons/src" (platform,src) => "platform/pl/src" (platform,gunit) => "platform/pl-gunit/src" (px,src) => "app-px/px/src" (px,gunit) => "app-px/px-gunit/src"

Parameters:
product - a two-letter app code
type - gunit, test, or anything else
Returns:

resolveRelativePath

public static java.io.File resolveRelativePath(java.io.File parent,
                                               java.lang.String relativePath)
Tries its darnedest to build a canonical file with a parent directory and a relative path.

Parameters:
parent - the parent directory to base the relative path
relativePath - the path relative to the parent directory
Returns:
new File(parent, relativePath).getCanonicalFile() or simply new File(parent, relativePath) if that doesn't work out for some reason

getRelativePath

public static java.lang.String getRelativePath(java.io.File baseDir,
                                               java.io.File file)
Produces a relative path string that describes one directory's location relative to another.

Parameters:
baseDir - the base directory from which to begin calculating the relative path
file - the file to be represented by the relative path
Returns:
the relative path from baseDir to file

fileUnderParent

public static java.lang.String fileUnderParent(java.io.File parent,
                                               java.io.File file)
Returns true if file is under parent

Parameters:
parent - a directory
file - a file
Returns:
a string representing the relative path from the parent to the file, or null if the file is not under the parent

getBestAvailableFile

public static java.io.File getBestAvailableFile(java.io.File fileToFix)

isRelativePath

public static boolean isRelativePath(java.lang.String path)
